awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Towards Dynamic Social Ride-sharing: An Essential Component in Smart and Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Prior work has demonstrated the potential economic and environmental benefits of ride-sharing; however, ride-sharing has not been adopted by the majority of travelers, since previous efforts aimed to maximize the number of participants but failed to take travelers social attributes into account. One of the major challenges in advocating ride-sharing is how to reduce social barriers. Taking advantage of advances in information technology and social media for building smart communities, and with emerging social attitudes regarding travel behavior, ride-sharing along with its social experience should be considered as a viable and possibly dominant mode of transportation in smart communities. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will address the current social barriers to ride-sharing and will provide more appealing ride matches leading to increased user participation. While a slight compromise in travel time may be tolerated by users in exchange of better social experience, the economy of scale in social ride-sharing would result in better performance of transportation systems in smart cities and communities. The project will support the realization of asocial ride-sharing system that can serve in validating the long-term research goals of deploying Social Transportation. 

The goal of this research is to develop theoretical foundations for supporting social ride-sharing. Users social attributes and preferences will be jointly determined by two innovative patterns: the spatial-activity pattern and the social-activity pattern. A probabilistic location clustering model will be built to identify abnormal non-commuting travels for the spatial-activity pattern. This project leverages a key word-search approach and topic recognition to estimate travelers social activities and travel purposes for the social-activity pattern. Novel optimization models for estimation of travel pattern from social media and ride-sharing data will be developed, to include using state-of-the-art matrix estimation techniques to infer various aspects of travel pattern, such as regular and special-pattern (anomalous) trips by type, time of day, day-of-week, etc. This step is particularly innovative in that these estimation methods are new to the transportation field, and their successful application would be beneficial to the research community. New theory will be developed for social ride-sharing in maximizing both riders satisfaction and trip efficiency. A living lab will be used in collaboration with local entities to demonstrate the pilot implementation of the research product.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop new methodologies for estimating travel demand patterns for informing transportation planners about ridesharing and other emerging modes. Specifically, our objective was to a) extract travel behavior information of transit users from automatic transit data, b) develop optimization models to estimate origin-destination matrices representing regular and special-event travel demand, and c) develop algorithms for optimal driver-passenger matching for first mile access to transit.

Towards the first objective, we developed a robust trip chaining algorithm to estimate transit passenger trajectories from smart card data considering different sources of error in the data. Trip chaining algorithms are becoming common in transit demand analysis but due to their deterministic structure, any incorrect inference carries over in the chain and leads to wrong trajectory estimation. Our proposed method considers GPS errors, transit vehicle delay, and user route choice preferences, and generates a set of likely trajectories, among which the most likely trajectory is selected. The method was applied to the student transit pass data in the Twin Cities region and results showed more estimation in quantity and quality. Results were used for analyzing travel behavior of students over multiple years and finding were communicated with the transit agency.

The second objective was fulfilled in a study on transit demand estimation for Minnesota State Fair. Transit systems usually encounter with large demand during special events and must provide additional capacity to carry new demand, which is usually concentrated around a small geographic area. However, there is no sound methodology to estimate the special event demand. We adopted compressed sensing methodologies common in image processing to estimate the regular and anomalous demand using historical passenger count data. Simply put, the observed demand matrix was decomposed to a regular demand matrix following a repetitive pattern, a sparse demand matrix for special-events, and a noise matrix. An optimization algorithm was developed to estimate the three component matrices using bus rapid transit (BRT) data during a one-month period containing the twelve days of Minnesota State Fair. Results show that the method can successfully detect the event and accurately estimate the additional demand during the state fair. Results were found effective in designing suitable service addition such that demand is served but resources are not wasted.

Lastly, for enhancing transportation systems through peer-to-peer ridesharing, we developed an optimization model to match drivers and riders such that riders are dropped off at the transit stop with the best service to their destinations. The method uses a schedule-based transit network and creates feasible matches using the concept of time-space prism considering drivers and riders time constraints. A matching optimization problem is then developed to find optimal driver-rider-stop triplets. The method was tested using synthetic demand data from Metropolitan Council of the Twin Cities along with schedule data from Metro Transit system. A rolling horizon simulation indicates that the system can greatly contribute in the reduction of the number vehicle trips and the number of vehicle-miles traveled.

Overall, the project lead to one MS thesis, 5 journal publications, and more than 10 conference presentations, along with multiple other graduate student research. It has reinforced collaboration with transportation agencies through data exchange and the communication of research results. By promoting transit and ridesharing systems, the research can contribute in reducing traffic congestion and its environmental impacts.
